characters: A HOPPING MAN IN A UNITARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: High in the air----so high we an see the curvature of the earth. The eastern seaboard stretches away, flecked with clouds. As we dissolve in closer the picture bleaches of color. are looking down at the city of Washington, D.C. Dissolve closer still: a black-and-white aerial photograp a neighborhood in suburban D.C. dominated by a sprawling building. Computer type quickly bleeps on: C.I.A. Headquarters Langley, Virginia

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We track at floor level, following the well shined shoes someone walking down the well polished hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear a door opening and a silver-haired man rises behi his desk. A nameplate on the desk identifies him as Palme DeBakey Smith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ozzie.    Sit down. Osbourne Cox, entering, is a middle-aged man in a striped shirt and bow tie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Palmer.   What's up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know Peck, and Olson. The two men, sitting on chairs facing the desk, nod at Osbourne, who is surprised to see them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peck, yes, hiya. Olson, by reputation. Hi, Osbourne Cox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, hiyah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you with...aren't you, uh... Palmer jumps in:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's right. Oz, look. There's no easy way to say this. We're taking you off the Balkans desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're----what? Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In fact we're moving you out of Sigint entirely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What?    No discussion, just----you're out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we're having the discussion now Oz. This doesn't have to be unpleasant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Palmer, with all due respect----what the fuck are you talking about? A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... And why is Olson here? Another uncomfortable beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Look, Ozzie----

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck is this?!     Is it my----I know it's not my work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ozzie----

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a great fucking analyst!     Is it----

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oz, things are not going well.      As you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a drinking problem. Stunned silence.         Ozzie turns to look at Peck. At length:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a drinking problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This doesn't have to be unpleasant. We found you something in State. It's a, uh... He gropes, uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... It's a lower clearance level. Yes. But we're not, this isn't, we're not terminating you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) This is an assault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Ozzie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is an assault. I have a drinking problem? Fuck you, Peck, you're a Mormon!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ozzie----

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next to you we all have a drinking problem! Fuck you guys! Whose ass didn't I kiss? Let's be honest! Palmer nods at Olson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Olson----

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's be fucking honest... Osbourne gets to his feet, agitated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... This is a crucifixion! This is political! Don't tell me it's not! He storms out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I have a drinking problem! The door slams.   Palmer Smith looks at Olson.     Olson an eyebrow.

dialogues.speaker: OSBOURNE
dialogues.text: Bow tie loosened, he stands at a kitchen counter. His shoulders twist as he does something below frame: we the crackle of ice cubes wrenching loose from a tray. Behind him we see the apartment door opening. Katie, an attractive middle-aged woman, enters, taking her key out the door, but stops, surprised to see Osbourne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're home. Osbourne continues making himself a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hang on to your hat, honey.    I have some news. I----

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you pick up the cheeses?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were they ready? I didn't know you were coming home this early.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blank)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cheeses. Katie rolls her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I left a message for you to stop at Todaro's. The Magruders and the Pfarrers are coming over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Pfarrers? Ugh.    I----what did Kathleen say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you left the message?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She said.    She would give you.   The message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well she, I don't know, I guess we had bigger news today. My day didn't revolve arou----

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you didn't get the cheeses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, since I didn't get the message, no, I didn't get the cheeses. But hang on to your hat, I----

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh for fuck's sake, Ozzie, you mean I have to go out again? All right, well, you better get dressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, we have to talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not right now. They'll be here in, what, less than an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hand hovers, hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this a, uh, goat cheese?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chevre, yes, that is a goat cheese. Pink Revision 8/14/07 6.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wider shows the cocktail party, meagerly attended but in swing. Besides Osbourne and Katie there is Harry Pfarrer (who has just inquired about the cheese), bearded, fortie rugged; his wife Sandy; and a shiny-faced young couple, D and Tina Magruder. Osbourne holds a cocktail tumbler. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I have lactose reflux.    But I can---- OSBOURNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're lactose intolerant? HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but I can---- OSBOURNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or you have acid reflux?    They're two different things. Harry looks at him coldly. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what they are. OSBOURNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you misspoke yourself.    So I---- HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for correcting me. KATIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should try the chevre, Harry. It's very good. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.   I can eat goat cheese. He eats a piece, cupping one hand under his mouth. HARRY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I was just explaining to your husband here, I have a condition---- Katie tries to separate the two men by including Doug Magruder. KATIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry works with the Marshalls'                       * Service.                                              * Pink Revision 8/14/07 6A.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG MAGRUDER
dialogues.text: Ah. I'm on the legislative side, I                 * work with Senator Hobby.                           * Pink Revision 8/14/07 7. HARRY                                       *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Used to work for Treasury, but I                      * didn't go over to Homeland Security.                  * I'm with the Marshalls.                               * OSBOURNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you want he'll show you his great big gun. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very amusing. The gun is actually no big deal. Twenty years in the marshall's service and I've never discharged my weapon. OSBOURNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like something you should be telling your psychiatrist. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?   I don't have a psychiatrist. DOUG MAGRUDER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, I guess my job is pretty undramatic. I'm on the legislative side. What do you do Mrs. Pfarrer? Do you also carry a gun? Harry laughs. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sandy writes children's books. SANDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I write children's books---- HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver The Cat Who...Who..arghh----Who---- Choking on piece of cheese, coughing HARRY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Who Lives In The Rotunda.     Excuse me. TINA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those are wonderful!    My nieces and nephews----

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's a beloved series. You wouldn't believe her fan mail. Unghh. Are you sure this is goat cheese?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you let your wife tell them about her own books, Harry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry----was I----

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, come in the kitchen, help me with the cruditГ©s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamnit.     He knows, doesn't he. He looks down at the floor.        He stamps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Nice floors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knows what? Harry is looking around the kitchen, taking in the fixtur Absently:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About us, he knows about us.          Little prick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be an ass, he doesn't know a thing. Harry is staring down at the linoleum again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that, forbo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car drives by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry driving, his wife next to him. A long beat. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a horse's ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know why we see them. Harry shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, she's all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is a cold, stuck-up bitch. Harry opens his mouth to reply, considers, doesn't. They drive.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: She is staring, in front of a mirror, face covered in col cream, one hand arrested on the way up to daub on more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You quit?! Osbourne is buttoning a pajama top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well----Thank you for letting me know!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tried to tell you this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tried? You tried? And then---- what, the aphasia kicked in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our guests came. We----

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: Why?!    For fuck's sake, Ozzie!

dialogues.speaker: OSBOURNE
dialogues.text: I'm just----I don't know.    I got so tired.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: You're tired.

dialogues.speaker: OSBOURNE
dialogues.text: Tired of swimming against the current.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: OSBOURNE
dialogues.text: Independent thought is not only not valued there, they resist it, they fight it, the bureaucracy is positively----

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: Did you get a pension, or severance or something, or----

dialogues.speaker: OSBOURNE
dialogues.text: I didn't retire you know, I, I quit. I don't want their benefits.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: But I suppose my benefits are all right, I suppose you can live with those, is that the idea?

dialogues.speaker: OSBOURNE
dialogues.text: It's not like that's the only way to make money.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: Yes?    Yes?     What're you gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: OSBOURNE
dialogues.text: I'll do some consulting.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: Consulting.

dialogues.speaker: OSBOURNE
dialogues.text: Yes, to help while I----I've always wanted to write.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: Write.    Write what.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been thinking about it.    A book, a sort of, sort of memoir. Katie stares at him in the mirror. A beat. She bursts into laughter.

dialogues.speaker: THE BRIDGE
dialogues.text: A small yacht. Osbourne stands at the wheel, a light wind his face, as the boat sails under motor power. After a beat he moves to the front of the boat. An old man sits on a bench on the prow facing out into th wind. He has snowy hair and a stern Yankee face. He wears tweed cap. He doesn't much react to Osbourne's approach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay there, Dad? The old man remains silent, staring. Osbourne sits next t him and idly tucks in the plaid blanket resting over the man's knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Dad, I left my job at the Agency... The old man stares out into the wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I, uh... I'm sorry. Dad, government service is not what it was when you were in State. Things are different now. I don't know, maybe it's... it's... the Cold War ending; now it seems like it's all bureaucracy and no mission... The old man stares out into the wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I'm writing a memoir. I think it's going to be pretty explosive. But I don't think you'll disapprove. I don't think you'll disapprove. Katie has had trouble accepting it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But... sometimes there's a higher patriotism, Dad. So we'll... Yes, change is hard. It's hard on Katie. But we'll be okay. We'll be okay. Life is change. This is good. We were all blocked up, Katie and me. This is, this is a blessing in disguise. I'll go into training, you know. Lay off the sauce. Like you did. You managed to do it. Finally. And then I can concentrate on, you know. New beginning. And this'll all have been for the best. Don't you think Dad? The old man stares out into the wind. Osbourne sniffles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Cold. He taps the old man on the knee and rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I guess we should head back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sailboat docked at the end of a marina. Osbourne is pushing the old man in a wheel chair down the pier away f the boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've seen this...

dialogues.speaker: THE MAN
dialogues.text: White hair, bushy eyebrows, a florid face. He is in a law book lined conference room. He wears an expensive suit, suspenders, a white shirt with blue collar and cuffs. He Bogus Terikhian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I know this kind of man.    We've seen this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wider on the conference room shows that Katie Cox sits at table, along with Terikhian, another lawyer, and an assistant. TERIKHIAN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Mrs. Cox, you can't let this man take advantage of you. And he will. He will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. This is my fear. He's trying---- he says----he's trying to pull himself together, but... TERIKHIAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, sure, I----I'm obliged to tell you you should try to salvage things. And you should. People turn themselves around. Not unheard-of. But. You---- you haven't broached the possibility of divorce yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. TERIKHIAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well that's good.   Because first you should get all his financials. Before he's forewarned. Because here's a man, here's a man, practiced in deceit, this is almost, you could say it's his job, practiced at hiding things, and there is no reason, it is not improper, there is no reason for you not to get a picture of the household finances. Paper files, computer files, whatever----this is your prerogative. You can be a spy too, madam. Do this before you put him on alert. Before the turtle can draw in his head and his, uh... He waggles his hands, groping for the word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Feet. He shrugs. TERIKHIAN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... And hopefully everything will work out. He will reform. But! If not: forewarned is forearmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Osbourne is splayed on an easy chair, wearing a bathrobe pyjamas. He stares at the ceiling, motionless, arms out- flung, like Marat in his bathtub. A long still beat.   A clock ticks. Abruptly Osbourne raises one hand to speak into a microcassette recorder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were young and committed and there was nothing we couldn't do. We thought of the Agency less as... less as... The thought, such as it was, peters out.   Osbourne rises wanders around the room, glassy-eyed. He suddenly raises the microcassette again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... The principles of George Kennan----a personal hero of mine----were what animated us. In fact they were what had originally inspired me to enter government service. Like the State Department's China Hands of yore, or, in a different forum, in a different venue, in a different medium, in, um... "Murrow's Boys," the fabled----in a different---- He suddenly stops, head cocked, listening. Faintly, a ringing phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the cut Osbourne is thundering down a steep carpeted stairway. He inclines his head to clear the ceiling that juts over the bottom half of the stairwell. The phone is louder here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A semi-finished basement with cheap paneling and a low dropped ceiling of water-stained Johnson-Armstrong tile. ringing phone is on a cheap government-surplus desk. The answering machine, with Osbourne's voice, picks up:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have reached The Cox Group... Osbourne, robe flapping, shuffles hurriedly in his slippe feet toward the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... We can't answer your call right now. Please leave a----

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (heavy breathing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. He eases into the chair, having swiped up the phone.    A listening beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Yes?... Oh, no... No, call her number... No, upstairs...No she's not, but leave it on her machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are looking over Osbourne's shoulder----he is still in robe----as he sits hunched on an ottoman, looking at a da game show. A few beats of the show. Roaring laughter from the studio audience.     Mild chuck Osbourne in the foreground.

dialogues.speaker: INT LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Ticking clock. Osbourne paces with the microcassette recorder. He raises it with a thought, draws a breath, an then stops, and looks off. The ticking grandfather clock: ornate hands on an ornate clock face Two or three minutes to five. Osbourne stares for a long beat.

dialogues.speaker: OSBOURNE
dialogues.text: Shoulders twisting as we hear ice clattering out of a tra He pours coke sizzling onto the ice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pauses for a long beat. He takes a bottle of rum out of a cabinet. He pours some into a hatch-marked shot glass. He looks at it. The amber liquid tops the hatch mark. conscientiously pours the overage back, murmuring:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Single... He dumps the shot into the Coke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As before, the boat, docked at the end of the marina pier seen in long shot through the windshield of a car. Closer on the boat. As water laps against pilings and the boat gently bobs and creaks, we hear, muffled, the sounds a couple having sex. When it builds to climax we cut:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minutes later. We hold on a door for a quiet beat, then w hear the gurgle of water, and then the door opens. Harry Pfarrer emerges from the small bathroom, buckling his bel In the bedroom which he emerges into Katie Cox is just finishing dressing. Harry looks at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should try to get a run in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katie is letting herself in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ozzie! Quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katie enters and sees a note on the counter paperweighted a plate of used lime wedges:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, At Fenninger's.     Reunion committee dinner. See you later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long-lens, hand-held, point-of-view seeming: Harry Pfarre jogging in his Treasury sweats. Closer on him.   Brow furrows.   He spins, jogs backwards looking. His point-of-view: nothing unusual; traffic on the bridge pedestrians particularly close. Harry, mildly puzzled, slows and stops.    He turns again Point-of-view up the bridge: empty. Harry starts jogging again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are tracking toward the desk in the corner, at which K sits. She cracks open a CD case and loads the CD into Osbourne's computer. A suspense drone builds as we track Katie starts typing, then suddenly stops. She holds still listening for noises in the house. Nothing. She resumes typing. We hear male voices beginning to swell in song. The voice continue after the suspense drone snaps off, at the cut t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A musty steakhouse. On the walls are hunting-scene prints and steel engravings of English country houses. A placard resting on a chair outside the Georgian Room: CLOSED FOR PRIVATE PARTY. From inside the room, male voices:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tune every heart and every voice...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dozen middle-aged men around a long table, each holding high a glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Bid every care withdraw.    Let all with one accord rejoice... The men are sweaty, tie-loosened, dinner-stuffed and booz

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... In praise of Old Nassau... Close on Osbourne as a rotund middle-aged classmate fills glass to brimming. The two sway unsteadily with the music

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... In praise of Old Nassau my boys, Hoo-rah, hoo-rah, hoorah! All swing their glasses side-to-side in rhythm:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Her sons... shall give... while they... shall live... Glasses are thrust high with a ringing finish:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... In praise of Old Nassau!

dialogues.speaker: A WOMAN'S ASS
dialogues.text: Bare.   Pale.   Middle-aged. Someone with a marker is drawing on the flesh to illustra

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We take all the chicken fat off your buttocks, here... and here... And the upper arms. And a little off your tummy... The camera is arcing around a standing, naked, middle-age woman, to reveal the doctor sitting on a stool in the examining room, facing her. He reaches forward again with the marker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOCTOR (OFF) (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And we do breast augmentation with a tiny incision here... and here. PATIENT (OFF)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.    And what about the thigh area? DOCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well we can do liposuction there as well, but that area will respond to exercise. Buttocks and upper arms begin to store more fat when you get up around forty, the body just tells it to go there, but the thighs will respond to toning exercises. PATIENT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. I know, I can work out on my arms til the cows come home, but... DOCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. And of course there are also genetic factors. PATIENT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Litzkes are big. DOCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh, well everything's---- PATIENT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mom had an ass that could pull a bus. DOCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow.    Well that's a predispo---- PATIENT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father's side too, although Dad tends to carry his weight in front of him. DOCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. PATIENT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the gut area. Derriere, not so much. DOCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. The continuing track around is also booming up to reveal face of the patient, Linda Litzke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what about the face, you know, the window to the soul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh! Uh-huh! Very well put. Well your eyes are one of your best features. But we can do something about the incipient crow's feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby crow's feet. Little chickling's feet. I mean chicks. Chickie chickie chickie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ha-ha, yes, again, well put. You have a way with words. We cut here... He marks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... And we pull the skin tight, like stretching the skin over a drum. Not too tight, though. We don't want that "worked-on" look. You need sufficient slack for the face to remain expressive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I don't wanna look like Boris Karloff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh! Heh-heh, so you don't want a sex change!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm all woman!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor and patient, now dressed, sit on either side of a desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Linda, what we're talking about here is four different procedures. (ticks them off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The liposuction... The rhinoplasty... The facial tuck, which I would strongly recommend over the chemical peel----

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I don't want to get anything burned off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And why should you. With that lovely skin. And lastly, the breast augmentation. Now we can also do something about the vaccine scar----I don't know if you wear sleeveless dresses much----

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not with these ham hocks!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, well once they're nice and svelte, post-op, you----

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

Harry fishes the phone out of his pocket and holds it at arm's length, squinting at the number. Still humming, he stuffs the phone back in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another couple of cycles.

dialogues.text: Isn't that somethin'? Hundred bucks all-in if you don't count my labor. And the, you know----cost of the dildo. Those things are not cheap.

He is about to open door but pauses, seeing: The parked car up the street. Katie's car having passed, now pulls out and follows at a discreet distance. Both ca disappear. Chad proceeds on to the house. There is a barred garden- level door tucked under the stoop. Chad checks out the caging on the door. He looks up the faГ§ade of the house.

dialogues.text: He spins, jogs backward. His point-of-view: a car, traveling slowly.   Following? Harry cuts across a park lawn.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Jogging, entering a residential area.

dialogues.text: Chad is emerging from the basement. He is looking idly around, heading toward the front door when a shape materializes in its frosted glass sidelight. Chad freezes. There is scraping at the lock. Chad quickly mounts the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chad freezes, listening. The downstairs door swings open, shut. Footsteps. A tread on the stairs: Chad scurries into the first open door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chad hotfoots into a closet and eases its door most of th way shut. The footsteps mount the stairs. Chad peeks out. His POV: The bed, bedclothes rumpled.    In the middle of bed, a wedge-cushion.

dialogues.text: Beyond, the open bedroom door shows a slice of hallway an stairs. Harry arrives at the top of the stairs. He nudges back a drape on the window at the top of the steps. He lo down one way, then the other. He lets the drape fall back and seems to relax. Harry enters the bedroom. He strips off his shirt and ste out of his pants on his way into the bathroom off the mas bedroom. He leaves the door open. Chad reaches gingerly for the closet door to close it but stops abruptly as we hear the shower turned off and the curtain whipped back. Harry emerges from the shower. He rinses off, humming "Born Free," and walks into the foreground pulling on shorts and shirt and a pair of dres pants that was draped across a bureau. Chad shrinks back into the closet as Harry approaches. stops, just outside the cracked door. Through the crack we see only the white of his shirt. Abruptly Harry turns his back to us and recedes into the and bends to pick something off the floor. Chad leans in ever so slightly to see, but draws back aga as Harry approaches. Chad looks over to his right: on a hanger, the brown pinstripe coat that matches Harry's pants. The closet door is thrown open. CHAD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuhhh! HARRY

dialogues.speaker: AHHHHHHHHHH
dialogues.text: Harry jerks up the gun which he's pulled from the shoulde holster in his other hand and----BAM----shoots Chad in th The gun bucks. Unused to the recoil and still screaming, Harry staggers back and trips over the edge of the bed an drops the weapon. He crabs briefly backward and then flips over and scrambl off on all fours. In the hallway he rises and tramples do the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops at the bottom of the steps, panting. He looks ba up the steps, trying to control his heavy breathing so th he can listen. A long silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer. He looks around.

dialogues.text: Harry enters.    He opens a drawer, closes it, opens anot

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry tops the stairs.       He pauses, looking at: The bedroom door, ajar. Inside, his gun lies on the floor. Harry takes cautious steps toward the door. He pauses at the cracked door.      Suddenly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hungh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He plunges through the door and runs for the gun and scoo it, dropping the knife. He stands and spins, panting. His point-of-view: the closet. Its door ajar. Legs protru into the room as if Chad, hidden within, is sitting with back against the closet wall contemplating his next move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry walks cautiously over. With a bare foot he experimentally waggles one of Chad's feet. Limp. Harry nudges the door. HARRY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Hello? It creaks fully open. HARRY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Omygod. Omygod. Chad's face is a powder-burned, chewed-up mess. HARRY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Omygod who are you. You fucker. Omygod. He gingerly crouches down. HARRY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... You fucker... He tries to avert his eyes as he feels in Chad's suit pockets. HARRY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Omygod, my god... Ungh... He comes away with a wallet and hastily stands. HARRY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Omygod... Inside are a few dollars and nothing else: no credit card driver's license; empty. HARRY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Oh my fuck... He straightens up again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I killed a fucking spook.    You fucker... He gazes down at the body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... What are you doing here, you fucker.

dialogues.text: Tracking behind his shoes down a different piece of hallw

dialogues.text: Palmer.    What's up.

dialogues.text: PALMER

dialogues.text: Kolyma-2? PALMER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm. PALMER

dialogues.text: PALMER
